content.title: Carotid Artery Dissection
content.summary: Carotid artery dissection is a tear in the arterial wall allowing blood to enter between layers, creating an intramural hematoma that may narrow or occlude the lumen. It is a significant cause of stroke in young and middle-aged adults.
content.definition: A separation of the layers of the carotid artery wall, typically between the intima and media, resulting in an intramural hematoma with potential luminal compromise

epidemiology.age_distribution: Peak in fifth decade, but occurs from youth to elderly
epidemiology.stroke_contribution: 10-25% of strokes in patients under 45 years

traumatic.major_trauma: Motor vehicle accidents, direct neck trauma

by_location.extracranial: More common (85%), typically 2-3cm distal to carotid bulb

classic_triad.headache_neck_pain: Present in 60-90%, often ipsilateral and severe
classic_triad.horner_syndrome: Present in 25-50%, due to sympathetic fiber involvement

clinical_presentation.time_course: Symptoms may precede stroke by hours to weeks

key_findings: Crescent sign (intramural hematoma on axial T1)

conventional_angiography.findings: String sign, rat-tail tapering, double lumen

antithrombotic.evidence: No RCT showing superiority of one over other

indications: Failure of medical therapy with ongoing ischemia

prognosis.stroke_risk: Highest in first 2 weeks, then decreases
prognosis.vessel_healing: Complete or near-complete in 60-80% by 3-6 months

definition.@value: Tear in the wall of the carotid artery creating an intramural hematoma with potential stroke risk

learning_objectives: Define carotid artery dissection and describe its pathophysiology
Identify risk factors and associated conditions
Recognize the classic clinical triad of presentation
Select appropriate imaging modality for diagnosis
Outline medical and interventional treatment options
clinical_pearls: Always consider dissection in young stroke patients
Horner syndrome with ipsilateral headache = think dissection
MRI T1 fat-sat best shows intramural hematoma crescent
No evidence anticoagulation is superior to antiplatelet
Most dissections heal spontaneously with medical therapy
